Review:
Limbo is a timeless indie masterpiece that redefined the puzzle-platformer genre with its minimalist yet deeply atmospheric approach. Developed by Playdead, the game immerses players in a haunting monochromatic world filled with mystery and danger.

The striking black-and-white visuals, combined with a chillingly minimalist sound design, create an eerie and unsettling atmosphere that grips you from start to finish. The puzzles are clever, intuitive, and seamlessly tied to the environment, offering just the right balance of challenge and satisfaction.

What makes Limbo stand out is its ability to tell a profound, thought-provoking story without a single word of dialogue. Its themes of survival, loss, and exploration resonate deeply, making it more than just a game, it's an experience.

For fans of atmospheric and emotionally driven games, Limbo is an absolute must-play. Its influence on the indie game scene is undeniable, and its haunting world will stay with you long after you’ve reached the end.

At first I thought the game was quite charming, I'm used to a bit of horror here and there from playing Little Nightmares and was expecting a similar experienced based on what I could see of the game. The beginning of the game definitely delivered on that but it was the last third of the game that lost me. I don't mind too much to die and figure out a puzzle, it'll give a nice aha moment when I finally figure it out but at a certain point it became more frustrating and less intuitive.

 The last third of the game was horrible in that it didn't really matter how many times you died, or how much time you spent on a puzzle because it was really poor at keeping consistency with newly introduced mechanics and it's sometimes unintuitive level design. I especially hated the gravity section as the switches used to hit it was so inconsistent in design each one looking completely different. There were about like 3 different designs, ones with arrows, one with no arrows and only a light that looks like other switches, and the arrow with a timer. It was frustrating trying to use the switches in that section not knowing if it would do one thing or the other, or even if it was a switch that could be turned off or a one time button. The arrows were also particularly annoying since it's easy to mistaken them as the direction to go instead of button to press when they break the previously introduced design.

It was just frustrating and time consuming, especially with the character controls functioning worse than a decent flash game. It was never really scary, or eerie or creepy, maybe shocking at times. While there may be parts I'd enjoy and found charming taking into account the overall experience; I would never recommend it to any one I know to play this game over other horror puzzle platformers. If you must, then buy it on sale. Otherwise when games go on sale just spend it on Little Nightmares, for a similar longer, more streamlined puzzle game, with actual tense moments and a well designed experience.

For a murky, two-dimension journey Limbo explores distinct ideas which games haven't thought about blending together in the graceful way that this does. It challenges inner phobias by wrapping them up as a boss battle with an overgrown insect, emulating a sense of sheer vertigo at lofty heights and leaving the player unescorted through the abyssal absence of light. In terms of the visuals, those dark contrast effects ensure that all of the details are sensationally left up to imagination. The manner in which Limbo provokes the fear of the unknown keeps you interested in overcoming every level.

LIMBO – A Peaceful Stroll Through a Nightmare

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5 – Went in expecting a cute puzzle game. Left emotionally damaged.)

Ah, LIMBO. A charming little platformer where you play as a small boy searching for his sister. Sounds wholesome, right? WRONG. This game is actually a terrifying, shadowy world filled with giant spiders, deadly traps, and physics puzzles that made me question my IQ.

The art style? Beautiful. The atmosphere? Haunting. The number of times I died in the dumbest ways possible? Too many to count. One moment, you're hopping across some logs, enjoying the eerie silence, and the next, a massive spider leg impales you out of nowhere. Thanks for the heart attack, Playdead.

The puzzles are brilliant, but half the time, I solved them by accident—usually by dying 17 times first. And the sound design? Let’s just say every little creak and crunch had me paranoid that something horrifying was about to happen (spoiler: it usually was).

Overall, LIMBO is a masterpiece—dark, unsettling, and weirdly addictive. 10/10, would get crushed by a falling boulder again. 🕷️⚫💀
